awd_titl_txt: RUI: Traveling Planetary-Scale Waves during Major Stratospheric Sudden Warming
awd_abstract_narration:
The abrupt breakdown of the wintertime polar vortex, known as sudden stratospheric warming, can significantly change near-surface weather activities. Precursory eastward traveling planetary-scale waves in the mesosphere are thought to play a triggering role in initiating such abrupt breakdown of the wintertime polar vortex, but their origin and importance are not well understood. The atmospheric response to the vortex's demise can in turn excite westward traveling planetary-scale waves and amplify atmospheric tidal disturbances. However, the impacts and mechanisms of these responses in the upper mesospheric and lower thermospheric region are still unclear. This project combines analysis from space-based (Aura Microwave Limb Sounder, or MLS and Sounding of the Atmosphere using the Broadband Emission Radiometry, or SABER) and ground-based sensors (network of high-frequency radars), reanalysis, and a global chemistry-climate model to further illuminate the roles and causes of these traveling waves and tidal disturbances with respect to sudden stratospheric warming. 

Understanding the impacts of these atmospheric perturbations may improve knowledge of space physics and the assessments of stratospheric ozone loss and wintertime climate evolution. Specifically, these perturbations can promote strong ionospheric variability that alters global communications and induce forcings that enhance the downwelling of ozone-destroying chemical species from the upper mesosphere. New insights on precursory mesospheric waves prior to the vortex breakdown can assist seasonal forecasting. Importantly, the research activities will offer experiential learning opportunities for undergraduates on cutting-edge research that is unique in South Carolina and the greater Southeastern Regions. While serving as frameworks for a doctoral thesis, project results will be incorporated into undergraduate and graduate courses at a state-supported Liberal Arts institution that is embarking on its first and only doctoral program in atmospheric science related degree.

por.por_cntn:
Known as sudden stratospheric warming (SSW), the abrupt breakdown of the wintertime polar vortex can be characterized by the reversal of the zonally-averaged wind over a deep layer that can span between the lower stratosphere to the upper mesosphere. The SSW occurrence can influence the near-surface weather, alter the transport of ozone-destroying chemical species into the stratosphere, and disturb the ionosphere affecting global communications. Using observations, reanalysis, and model simulations, this project focused on understanding the existence and roles of traveling planetary-scale waves during SSW that contribute to the impacts of SSW. Project activities provided five undergraduates unique experiential learning opportunities at a primarily undergraduate institution and as part of an NSF-supported Research Experiences for Undergraduate (REU) program. In addition, these activities trained two graduate students, leading to the completion of their doctoral theses, and launched their careers as post-doctoral fellows in Atmospheric Sciences.

The research revealed the importance of eastward-propagating planetary-scale waves (EPWs), westward-propagating planetary-scale waves (WPWs), and migrating atmospheric tidal disturbance during the different phases of SSW evolution. A few weeks before SSW onset, EPWs arose from barotropic/baroclinic instability in the mesospheric flow. During SSW, EPWs appeared as trapped disturbances within the deep wind-reversal layer and triggered by gravity wave drag near the top of this layer. Concurrently, strong WPWs grew within the wind-reversal layer from barotropic/baroclinic instability. The dampening of WPWs well above the wind-reversal layer promoted the polar vortex’s recovery and strong polar descent of ozone-destroying nitric oxide from the altitude of 150 km down to the mesosphere. Roughly a week after SSW onset, the increased equatorial ozone heating and hemispheric symmetry in the background zonally-averaged wind due to SSW led to the amplified migrating semidiurnal tidal response that strongly perturbed the lower ionosphere in the Northern Hemisphere.

Furthermore, the project found that the prolonged duration and increased intensity of SSW (which can enhance cold air outbreaks over the continental regions) may be associated with the sea-ice retreat in the Chukchi-Bering Seas during the easterly phase of the Quasi-Biennial Oscillation. The regional sea-ice loss induced near-surface warming that can persist into winter and deepen as SSW develops. The associated temperature contrasts can elicit a strong upward planetary-scale wave activity into the stratosphere, that reinforces the climatological wave pattern, resulting in an intense and prolonged SSW.
